datasetPresenter.name: cparIowaII_bld36_annotation_GFF_GFF_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: The previous annotation for C. parvum IOWA II from release 36
datasetPresenter.description: The previous annotation for C. parvum IOWA II from release 36

datasetPresenter.name: cspchipmunkLX2015_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and assembly for Cryptosporidium sp. chipmunk LX-2015
datasetPresenter.description: Cryptosporidium chipmunk genotype I is an emerging zoonotic pathogen. In order to develop subtyping tools to determine the role of zoonotic transmission in cryptosporidiosis epidemiology, a human isolate of chipmunk genotype I oocysts was sequenced on an Illumina Genome Analyzer IIx (Illumina). Single-end 100-base pair reads were assembled using the CLC Genomics Workbench (CLC Bio), and contigs were mapped to the published whole-genome sequences of C. parvum using Mauve. In total, 9,009,492 bp in 150 contigs were mapped, resulting in 98.98% coverage of the genome.

datasetPresenter.name: cparIowaII_bld36Transcripts_transcript_sequences_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Transcripts for C. parvum IOWA II from CryptoDB Release 36.
datasetPresenter.description: Transcript sequences from the annotation of Cryptosporidium parvum IOWA II as presented in CryptoDB release 36.

datasetPresenter.name: ctyzUGA55_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Cryptosporidium tyzzeri isolate UGA55 sequence and annotation
datasetPresenter.description: Cryptosporidium tyzzeri UGA55 (C. parvum mouse genotype I) is an intestinal parasite isolated from naturally infected Mus domesticus by Adam Stariale, Jan Slapeta and Boris Striepen. The highest burden of C. tyzzeri infection is found in the distal ileum of the mouse small intestine, yet there is also significant infection of the jejunum and duodenum, similar to what is seen in human cryptosporidiosis. Paired-end Illumina sequence reads were assembled into contigs using the velvet assembler software and contigs were scaffolded by using a C. parvum Pacbio guided assembly using SSPACE-longreads.

datasetPresenter.name: chom30976_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Cryptosporidium hominis isolate 30976 sequence and annotation
datasetPresenter.description:
The isolate was firstly described at Guo et al. (2015) "Comparative genomic analysis reveals occurrence of genetic recombination in virulent Cryptosporidium hominis subtypes and telomeric gene duplications in Cryptosporidium parvum". Specimen 30976 was collected from a patient in a cryptosporidiosis outbreak in July 2010 in the St. Louis area in Illinois and Missouri associated with swimming pools and a water park. Whole genome amplification (WGA) of the 25–100 ng of extracted DNA was conducted by using the REPLI-g Midi Kit (Qiagen). The WGA products from specimens 30976 and 37999 were used to generate Illumina TruSeq (v3) libraries (average insert size: 350 bp) and sequenced 100×100 bp paired-end on an Illumina Genome Analyzer IIx (Illumina, San Diego, CA).
The annotation was performed by Kissinger's Research Group and the manuscript "Consistent, comparative and evidence-based genome annotation and re-annotation for the closely-related species, Cryptosporidium parvum, C. hominis and C. tyzzeri" with all specs will be available soon.

datasetPresenter.name: cand30847_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Cryptosporidium andersoni solate 30847 sequence and annotation
datasetPresenter.description: Cryptosporidium andersoni 30847 was isolated from beef cattle in Alberta Canada in 2009. PCR-RFLP analysis and DNA sequencing of the small subunit RNA confirmed Cryptosporidium species. Genomic DNA from purified oocysts was sequenced on an Illumina Genome Analyzer IIX and the genome was assembled de novo using CLC Genomics Workbench 7.03. Protein-coding genes were predicted using a pipeline of three software packages, including AUGUSTUS 2.7, SNAP, and GeneMark-ES.

datasetPresenter.name: cubi39726_primary_genome_RSRC

Isolation source: stool

Host age: 12
Host description: Diarrhea, Abdominal pain or cramping
Host sex: Female

Total RNA was polyA selected using oligo(dT) beads and RNA-seq libraries were prepared using TruSeq RNA Sample Prep kit (catalog no. FC-122-1001).

datasetPresenter.name: cvelCCMP2878_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome Sequence and Annotation for Chromera velia CCMP2878
datasetPresenter.description:
The genome sequence and annotation of Chromera velia CCMP2878 was produced by a consortium led by KAUST (King Abdullah University of Science and Technology). The aim is to understand the evolution of parasitism in the apicomplexa. The sequence and annotation is currently not published.

For questions please contact Yong.Woo@kaust.edu.sa.

datasetPresenter.name: vbraCCMP3155_primary_genome_RSRC

datasetPresenter.description:

datasetPresenter.name: gnipUnknown_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome Sequence and Annotation for Gregarina niphandrodes
datasetPresenter.description:
Gregarina niphandrodes genome sequence data were produced by JCVI. The genome was sequenced using 454 GS FLX Titanium and Illumina technology to a coverage of 39.68X. The genome was assembled with Newbler v. 2.6. EuPathDB downloaded the data from GenBank.

Data Usage Policy

The G. niphandrodes gDNA was extracted from gametocytes collected from the feces of infected beetles by Dr. Charlotte Omoto at Washington State University.

NIAID is committed to rapid, pre-publication release of genomic data and recognizes that clinical data and other metadata associated with the genomic data are valuable research resources. For these reasons, NIAID endorses rapid release of all genome data sets. To comply with this policy, the whole genome sequences of T. gondii strains are being submitted to NCBI and included here in ToxoDB prior to complete annotation. Once annotation is complete and submitted to GenBank, the entries for these new genomes will be updated in ToxoDB. The users of any released data are expected to act responsibly to recognize the scientific contribution of the data producers by following normal standards of scientific etiquette and fair use of unpublished data. In particular, we ask that users not perform genome wide comparisons/analyses of the sequence/open reading frames/genes of the data sets deposited here without first contacting the organizing committee. We welcome your input in this process, but would also like to coordinate community efforts to with the goal of producing a collective report for publication. If you have an idea for analyses that would be useful, please contact one of us to coordinate your contribution to the community effort.


Brian Brunk, Hernan Lorenzi, David Roos & David Sibley, on behalf of the Toxoplasma genome consortium, representing the white paper committee, the JCVI genome sequencing center, and the ToxoDB team.

datasetPresenter.name: cparIowaII_dbxref_protein2EinsteinAntibodies_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description:
Antibodies against C. parvum epitopes generated by the Albert Einstein Biodefense Proteomics Research Center.
Antibodies may be obtained for free from the Biodefense and Emerging Infections Research Resources Repository.

datasetPresenter.name: cmurRN66_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Cryptosporidium muris RN66
datasetPresenter.description:
Cryptosporidium muris RN66 sequence and annotation downloaded from GenBank.

Cryptosporidium muris predominantly infects rodents, although a gradually increasing number of human infections have been reported. This species has adapted to living in the stomach, while other Cryptosporidium species have adapted to living in the small and large intestine.

This project represents roughly 13x hybrid coverage (about 4.5x Sanger and 10x 454) of the genome. Annotation was added to the scaffolds in October 2008.

datasetPresenter.name: cparIowaII_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Cryptosporidium parvum IowaII
datasetPresenter.description:
Cryptosporidium parvum IowaII genome sequence and annotation downloaded from GenBank.

Cryptosporidium parvum Iowa II is an intestinal parasite. Genomic DNA was purified from the parasite oocyst stage, randomly sheared and used to construct plasmid libraries of 2 – 5 kb fragments in length and sequenced to generate a 13-fold genome coverage. A 0.5-fold genome coverage was generated by end sequencing of large-insert (15 kb) lamba clones. Individual sequence reads were assembled into contigs using the PHRED/PHRAP/CONSED analysis software and contigs were assigned and orientated on chromosomes with the aid of HAPPY map markers (S2).

link.text: Whole Genome Shotgun Sequencing page at NCBI/GenBank

datasetPresenter.name: cparIowaII_HTS_SNP_Widmer_HTS_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Aligned genomic sequence reads - TU114 Strain
datasetPresenter.summary: SNPs determined by aligning high throughput sequencing reads of C. parvum TU114 to the C. parvum reference genome
datasetPresenter.description:
High throughput sequencing of Cryptosporidium parvum TU114 analyzed for single nucleotide polymorphisms to C. parvum.

Parasites
C. parvum isolate TU114 was isolated from a Ugandan child in 2003 and has since been maintained by serial propagation in immunosuppressed mice. This isolate was previously described in the context of a crossing experiment (Tanriverdi et al., 2007). TU114 was genotyped with several polymorphic micro- and minisatellite markers (Tanriverdi & Widmer, 2006, Widmer & Lee, 2010). Its genotype is characteristic of a group of C. parvum isolates which are predominantly or exclusively transmitted among humans and carry the GP60 (GP40/15) IIcA5G3b allele characterized by a short repeat of only 8 serine residues. Isolate TU114 has never been cloned. To generate DNA for sequencing, immunosuppressed CD-1 mice were orally inoculated with oocysts. When oocysts were first detected in the feces by the microscopic analysis of stained fecal smears (Ma & Soave, 1983), mice were transferred to cages with a wire bottom and feces collected daily. Oocysts were purified on step gradients of Histodenz (Widmer et al., 1998). To remove foreign DNA, oocysts were briefly suspended in a 10% solution of commercial bleach. Thereafter, oocysts were subjected to three cycles of freezing and thawing, and DNA extracted with the HighPure DNA isolation kit (Roche Diagnostics, Indianapolis, IN).

Sequencing Genomic DNA from isolate TU114 was fragmented, ligated to Illumina adapters and the library loaded onto one lane of a flow cell. The library was sequenced in an Illumina Genome AnalyzerII with 50-bp paired-end reads. A total of 22,125,448 reads were obtained, 21,483,810 (97.15%) of which mapped to the C. parvum reference genome (accession # NZ AAEE00000000).

datasetPresenter.name: cparIowaII_HTS_SNP_Feng_Comparative_Single_End_HTS_SNPs_RSRC

datasetPresenter.description: This project is to compare different isolates of Cryptosporidium spp. at whole genome level to identify genetic determinants for phonotypic traits such as host specificity and virulence, and for high-resolution tracking of transmission in humans and animals.

datasetPresenter.name: cparIowaII_HTS_SNP_Gilchrist_Genetic_Diversity_Bangladesh_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Cryptosporidium hominis genetic diversity in isolates from Bangladesh
datasetPresenter.summary: Cryptosporidium hominis genetic diversity in isolates from Bangladesh
datasetPresenter.description: Genome sequencing of Cryptosporidium hominis from infants in slum dwelling from Dhaka Bangladesh. Cryptosporidium oocysts were purified directly from stool samples of 2 grams of semi-solid stool or approximately 2 mL of liquid stool material using the protocol of Hadfield et al. In 32 samples the sequences were both derived from C. hominis and had >80% genome coverage of 10X. Fifteen of these were diarrheal isolates and seventeen were isolated from subclinical infections as defined by Steiner et al.

datasetPresenter.name: chomTU502_HTS_SNP_Sikora_Clinical_Stool_Samples_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Genomic variation in patient-derived Cryptosporidium hominis samples
datasetPresenter.summary: Genomic variation in patient-derived Cryptosporidium hominis samples
datasetPresenter.description: Genomic DNA from 14 clinical C. hominis stool samples collected from 2013-2015 was extracted using target-specific immunomagnetic separation (IMS) with anti-Cryptosporidium Dynabeads (Thermo Fisher) followed by a QIAamp DNA minikit. A library for each sample was created by fragmenting the DNA and adding adaptors to the ends, using an Ion Xpress Plus fragment library kit for an AB Library Builder system (Thermo Fisher) according to the manufacturers autoshearing program for a 400-bp library without size selection. The samples were amplified then size selected using Pippin Prep (Sage Science) and purified using AMPure beads (Beckman Coulter). The size selected libraries were clonally amplified using an Ion Chef system and an Ion One Touch 2 system (Thermo Fisher) and then used for whole-genome sequencing on an Ion Torrent Personal Genome Machine (PGM) using an Ion PGM IC 200/400 kit and an Hi-Q sequencing kit (Thermo Fisher).

datasetPresenter.name: chomTU502_HTS_SNP_Gilchrist_Genetic_Diversity_Bangladesh_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Cryptosporidium hominis genetic diversity in isolates from Bangladesh
datasetPresenter.summary: Cryptosporidium hominis genetic diversity in isolates from Bangladesh
datasetPresenter.description: Genome sequencing of Cryptosporidium hominis from infants in slum dwelling from Dhaka Bangladesh. Cryptosporidium oocysts were purified directly from stool samples of 2 grams of semi-solid stool or approximately 2 mL of liquid stool material using the protocol of Hadfield et al. In 32 samples the sequences were both derived from C. hominis and had >80% genome coverage of 10X. Fifteen of these were diarrheal isolates and seventeen were isolated from subclinical infections as defined by Steiner et al.

datasetPresenter.name: cparIowaII_massSpec_Ferrari_LTQ_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Proteome of intact oocyst, oocyst wall and sporozoite of C. parvum IowaII determined by linear ion trap mass spec
datasetPresenter.description: Cryptosporidium parvum IowaII oocyst, oocyst wall and sporozoite proteomes from linear ion trap (LTQ) mass spectrometer analysis of .

datasetPresenter.name: cparIowaII_massSpec_Wastling_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description:
C. parvum sporozoite peptides from 2D gel LC-MS/MS analysis.
Purified oocysts of Cryptosporidium parvum IowaII passaged in lambs were excysted. Freshly excysted sporozoites were solubolized and protein preparations were analyzed by 2 dimensional electrophoresis LC-MS/MS. Spectra were searched against a Cryptosporidium database using SEQUEST. SEQUEST results were assembled and filtered using the DTASelect (version 2.0) program.

datasetPresenter.name: cparIowaII_SNP_Widmer_gff_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Aligned genomic sequence reads - TU114, MD, IOWA Strains
datasetPresenter.summary: High throughput sequencing data from C. parvum isolates TU114, MD and Iowa were analyzed for single nucleotide polymorphisms using C. parvum IowaII as a reference genome.
datasetPresenter.description: Isolates MD and TU114, were maintained and crossed in adult immunosuppressed C57BL/6 mice (1 mg dexamethasone phosphate administered every second day (Yang et al., 2000)). Six days after the first injection, mice were infected orally with ~1000 oocysts. Oocysts were purified from mouse feces as previously described (Widmer et al., 1998). Briefly, samples were homogenized and the oocysts floated on a 15%/30% (w/v) Histodenz (N,N'-bis(2,3-dihydroxypropyl)acetamido-2,4,6-tri-iodo-isophthalamide) (Sigma, St. Louis, Miss.) step gradient. Oocysts were sometimes further purified with immunomagnetic separation using the Aureon Crypto Kit (Aureon Biosystems, Vienna, Austria). DNA was extracted from purified oocysts with the High Pure Template Preparation Kit (Roche Diagnostics, Indianapolis, Ind.) (Tanriverdi et al., 2002). DNA was eluted in 20-50 ul TE buffer, a concentration equivalent to 10^4 oocysts/ul. SNPs differentiating the isolates MD and TU114 were identified by sequencing randomly chosen fragments of 2-2.5 kb retrieved from the C. parvum genome sequence. Fragments were spaced at approximately 80 kb. PCR primers 20-30 bp long were designed with vector NTI software. PCR included approximately 10 ng DNA of parental isolates MD or TU114, 0.4 µM primers and PCR mix (Takara) to a final volume of 50µl. Amplifications were performed with the following temperature condition: denaturation at 94°C for 2 min was followed by 35 cycles of 94°C for 30 s, 50-55°C for 30 sec, 68°C for 1.5 2 min, and a final 5 min extension at 68°C. A portion of 5µl of each PCR product was run on 1% agarose. For PCR reactions giving a single band, 5µl PCR product was treated with 2 µl of ExoSAP-IT (USB) at 37°C for 30 min and 80°C for 15 min. If multiple PCR bands were present, the entire PCR reaction was run on a 1% agarose gel and the desired band extracted with a QIAquick gel extraction. PCR products were sequenced using two pairs of primers of opposite polarity located at 700-800 bp intervals. Primers were designed such that adjacent complementary sequences overlapped by 50-100 bp. Portions of approximately 50 ng PCR product (~50 ng) were used in 15 µl sequencing reactions (CEQ DTCS-Quick Start Kit). Sequencing reactions were run on a CEQ8000 Genetic Analysis System (Beckman Coulter). Sequences were analyzed the Contig Express program in Vector NTI. MD and TU114 sequences were aligned to find SNPs. Any SNP was confirmed in a minimum of two sequences. Some SNPs were also confirmed by independent PCR amplification of the genomic DNA .

datasetPresenter.name: cparIowaII_rtpcr_Kissinger_RtPcr_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Expression profiling of life cycle stages post-infection
datasetPresenter.summary: Expression profiling of Cryptosporidium parvum during in vitro development determined by high throughput RT-PCR.
datasetPresenter.description:
Cryptosporidium parvum IowaII strain oocysts were stored at 4°C. HCT8 cell infection was carried out according to previously reported conditions. Oocysts were counted using a hemocytometer and 2-2.5 x 107 oocysts were added to each culture dish at time (t) = 0 hr and incubated at 37°C and 5% CO2 After visual confirmation of excystation and attachment in culture (t= 2 hr), all samples were rinsed with warmed 1x Hanks buffered saline solution (HBSS). Infected cell cultures were lysed in TRIzol (Invitrogen) at 2, 6, 12, 24, 36, 48, and 72 hours post infection and stored at -80°C until RNA isolation. RNA was isolated from the samples and DNA contamination was degraded utilizing the Turbo DNA-free kit. cDNA synthesis was accomplished using Superscript III cDNA synthesis kit. Real Time PCR utilizing C. parvum 18S ribosomal RNA primers was completed to verify lack of DNA contamination as well as confirmation of successful cDNA synthesis for all 7 time points over 4 independent infection time courses (biological replicates).

For RT-PCR, Twenty microliter reactions were constructed using a 4 ul of template from a 1:100 dilution of synthesized cDNA (2 ug RNA starting concentration), 0.1 uM primer pairs and 2x AccuQuant SYBR Green SuperMix, with Low Rox (Quanta BioSciences, Inc.). RT-PCR was run on Stratagene Mx3000P or Mx3005P thermacyclers , with cycle conditions of: 1 cycle of initial denaturation (95°C for 1 minute), 45 PCR cycles (95°C for 1 minute, 58°C for 30 seconds and ramping to 60°C for 30s). Amplification was followed by melt curve generation via 1 minute at 95°C ramping down to 57°C in 2 degree intervals followed by ramping back up to 95°C for 30 seconds.

Primers for individual genes were tested on C. parvum genomic DNA for amplicon formation and efficiency. RT-PCR of the infection time course cDNA was performed in a 96 well format, with each of the 3281 gene primers (12 per plate) normalized to the corresponding time point's 18s rRNA amplification on each plate. Because of the high-throughput nature, each gene of interests' initial RNA concentration was estimated by fitting a 4 point logistic curve to the raw fluorescence amplification plot for each gene and 18s rRNA reactions. Post-normalization the median of the replicates (2-7 with an average of 4) was calculated for each time point. Standardization was performed relative to the maximum expression of a gene across time points

datasetPresenter.name: chomTU502_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Cryptosporidium hominis TU502 sequence and annotation
datasetPresenter.description:
Whole genome sequence and annotations from the C. hominis whole genome sequencing project.
A modified whole-genome shotgun strategy was used to sequence the ~9.2-Mb genome of C. hominis isolate TU502, which was derived from an infected child from Uganda. DNA was purified from surface-sterilized oocysts, shotgun and BAC clones were constructed, and end sequences were generated. About 220,000 sequence reads from small insert clones, and end sequences from ~2,000 BAC clones averaging ~35 kbp in size, were generated. The data represents a ~12-fold shotgun clone coverage of the genome with a quality score of Phred 20, and a 7–8-fold coverage with BAC clones. The sequences were assembled with Phrap, yielding a ~9.16-Mb assembly, which was structurally and functionally analysed with a variety of available software programs and in-house scripts

datasetPresenter.name: chomTU502_2012_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Cryptosporidium hominis isolate TU502_2012 sequence and annotation
datasetPresenter.description:
Cryptosporidium hominis isolate TU502_2012, isolated in 2012 at Tufts University (USA) was a result of multiple (approximately 20) passages of the original TU502 isolate (2004) in gnotobiotic pigs. The Cryptosporidium hominis TU502_2012 genome sequence was generated as part of the Cryptosporidium sequencing white paper and should be distinguished from the genome of Cryptosporidium hominis TU502.
Comparison between the original Cryptosporidium hominis TU502 and Cryptosporidium hominis TU502_2012 shows higher than expected variation suggesting that these two isolates have either diverged significantly or that they are in fact two different strains. While the current isolate designation is TU502_2012, this may change in the future to better reflect its history.
The Cryptosporidium hominis TU502_2012 genome sequence was generated by the Institute for Genome Sciences (University of Maryland)as part of the Cryptosporidium sequencing white paper. The original assembly of this sequence was named TU502_New but renamed to TU502_2012 after comparison with the parental TU502 isolate.
datasetPresenter.history: data source changed, change-strain-name, sequence-changed, newly-annotated

link.text: RNAseq data used to guide the annotation of this genome

datasetPresenter.name: chomUdeA01_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Cryptosporidium hominis UdeA01 sequence and annotation
datasetPresenter.description:
Whole genome sequence and annotation for C. hominis UdeA01, that was directly isolated from an infected human.

Isolate and Genotype:
This strain was isolated in 2013 from the stool of an HIV positive woman from Columbia, South America. The isolate was typed using two highly polymorphic genes (HSP70 and GP60) and was found to belong to the subtype family Ie and the assigned subtype was IeA11G3T3. This isolate represents the first reference genome for the American continent and the first of the subtype family Ie available.

DNA Purification:
Oocysts were purified from a fecal sample collected from an HIV positive female Colombian patient by flotation in a saturated NaCl solution. There was no animal model for parasite propagation and oocyst production prior to DNA preparation.

Sequencing and Assembly:
The genome sequence is the result of a hybrid sequencing strategy that involved whole genome shotgun in the 454 FLX(+) and Miseq 2 × 250 platforms to a coverage of 68X for the BLASTN selected contigs. Low quality reads were removed using PRINSEQ. For de novo genome assembly, NEWBLER version 2.9 was used with default parameters. Because of sample contamination with human reads, Cryptosporidium assembled contigs were selected using BLASTN. These contigs were assigned with ABACAS to pseudo-chromosomes using as reference C. parvum Iowa chromosomes. Furthermore, some gaps were closed by 12 iterations of IMAGE. RATT was used to automatically transfer C. parvum Iowa genome annotation to the C. hominis UdeA01 pseudo-chromosomes, followed by manual inspection of the coding regions in ARTEMIS.

datasetPresenter.name: cparIowaII_EST_Watanabe_EstLibrary_sequences_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: The EST Library for Cryptosporidium parvum HNJ-1

Junichi Watanabe1, Hiroyuki Wakaguri2, Kazumi Abe2, Yutaka Suzuki2, Sumio Sugano2, Xuenan Xuan3 and Isao Kimata4
1Department of Parasitology, Institute of Medical Science. 2Department of Medical Genomics, Graduate School of Frontier Sciences, The University of Tokyo. 3National Research Center for Protozoan Diseases, Obihoro University of Agriculture and Veterinary Medicine. 4Department of Protozoal Diseases, Graduate School of Medicine, Osaka City University.

datasetPresenter.name: cparIowaII_massSpec_Lowery_LC_MSMS_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Proteome during C. parvum strain ISSC162 excystation. Soluble and insoluble fractions of both non-excysted and excysted sporozoites were analyzed.
datasetPresenter.description:
Peptides from LC-MS/MS analysis of fraction of C. parvum ISSC162 sporozoites

C. parvum oocysts (strain code ISSC162) were recovered from experimentally infected calves and half of the oocysts were excysted. Excysted and non-excysted oocysts were fractionated into soluble and non-soluble fractions and LC-MS iTRAQ analysis was performed on three samples:
1. insoluble excysted Fraction
2. insoluble non-excysted fraction
3. soluble excysted and non-excysted fraction.

datasetPresenter.name: cparIowaII_massSpec_Putignani_RSRC

datasetPresenter.name: cparIowaII_Lippuner_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcriptome of sporozoites and HTC-8 infection time course
datasetPresenter.summary: Transcriptomes of freshly excysted C. parvum sporozoites as well as parasites collected 48- and 96- hours post-infection in HTC8 cells were determined by SOLiD, paired end, strand-specific RNA sequencing.
datasetPresenter.description:
Transcriptomes of sprozoites and an infection time course.

C. parvum RNASeq experiment on samples isolated from sporozoites, intestine of calves and in vitro samples infected with parasites..

Sporozoites:
C. parvum oocysts (isolate IPZ:CH-Crypto_K6769) were excysted in 10 mM HCl for 10 min at 37°C, followed by 2 mM sodium taurochlate in PBS for 16 min at 37°C.

Infection time course samples:
HCT-8 cells were infected with C. parvum sporozoites (isolate IPZ:CH-Crypto_K6769) and incubated for 48 and 96 h.

Sequencing
Total RNA was isolated and purified. Two rounds of polyA-RNA selection were done to eliminate ribosomal RNA contamination Material was sequenced using SOLiD5500xl, paired end (75bp fwd+35bp rev), strand specific methods.

templateInjector.prop: Time points of Calf Small Intestine, HCT-8 infected cells and sporozoites

datasetPresenter.name: cparIowaII_Widmer_IntraExtra_Cellular_Stages_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcriptome of oocyst and intracellular stages
datasetPresenter.summary: Cryptosporidium parvum transcriptome from intracellular (24 h post-infection) and oocysts Stages.
datasetPresenter.description: Cryptosporidium parvum transcriptome in intracellular stages at 24 h post-infection and in oocysts. The transcriptome of four replicate infected cultures and four uninfected cultures was sequenced together with RNA from a single oocyst sample.

datasetPresenter.name: cparIowaII_Isaza_Infection_Time_Series_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcriptome of 48 hours in vitro infection
datasetPresenter.summary: Transcriptome (RNA sequence) from Cryptosporidium parvum Iowa isolated from an in vitro infection of cultured HCT-8 cells.
datasetPresenter.description: RNA sequence from Cryptosporidium parvum Iowa obtained from a 48 hours in vitro infection time-course of cultured HCT-8 cells. This data was generated for the purpose of reannotation hence all 8 samples were pooled.

templateInjector.prop: pooled 8 samples - 48 hours time-course in vitro infection of cultured HCT-8 cells

datasetPresenter.name: cparIowaII_Widmer_ExtraCellular_Stages_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcriptome of C. parvum sporozoites treated with GalNAc
datasetPresenter.summary: Transcriptome of C. parvum sporozoites treated with GalNAc to induce differentiation
datasetPresenter.description: Human cryptosporidiosis is caused primarily by two Cryptosporidium species, C. parvum and C. hominis. The enteric infection is frequent in infants living in developing regions. Cryptosporidium parasites are cultured in monolayers of epithelial cells. Gal-GalNAc has been shown to induce differentiation of sporozoites. To better understand parasite-host interactions in the presence of GalNAc, the C. hominis and C. parvum transcriptomes from oocysts and sporozites at 0h and 2h post-infection were analyzed. C. parvum sporozoites were incubated in either PBS or 10 uM GalNac for 0h (2 replicates each) or 2h (5 replicates each). RNA from 2 C. hominis oocyst samples (see dataset: Transcriptome of C. hominis oocysts) and a single C. parvum oocyst sample were also sequenced on an Illumina HiSeq 2500.

datasetPresenter.name: chomTU502_Widmer_oocysts_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Transcriptome of C. hominis oocysts
datasetPresenter.description: Human cryptosporidiosis is caused primarily by two Cryptosporidium species, C. parvum and C. hominis. The enteric infection is frequent in infants living in developing regions. Cryptosporidium parasites are cultured in monolayers of epithelial cells. Gal-GalNAc has been shown to induce differentiation of sporozoites. To better understand parasite-host interactions in the presence of GalNAc, the C. hominis and C. parvum transcriptomes from oocysts and sporozites at 0h and 2h post-infection were analyzed. C. parvum sporozoites were incubated in either PBS or 10 uM GalNac for 0h (2 replicates each) or 2h (5 replicates each). RNA from 2 C. hominis oocyst samples and a single C. parvum oocyst sample were also sequenced on an Illumina HiSeq 2500. This dataset only contains the C. hominis transcriptomes. The remaining data can be found in the dataset named “Transcriptome of C. parvum sporozoites treated with GalNAc”.

datasetPresenter.name: cparIowaII_Widmer_intracellularStages_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcriptome of C. parvum intracellular stages
datasetPresenter.summary: Transcriptome of C. parvum intracellular stages
datasetPresenter.description: To better understand parasite-host interactions, the transcriptome of cultured MDBK cells infected with Cryptosporidium parvum was analyzed. Four to five replicate samples of MDBK cells were sequenced 2h, 24h, and 48h post-infection. The 2-h and 24-h samples were infected with C. parvum isolate MD, whereas the 48-h samples were infected with C. parvum isolate TU114. Host cell transcriptome data can be accessed through the corresponding HostDB dataset page.

datasetPresenter.name: cparIowaII_microarrayExpression_Zhu_GSE34307_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Oocyst Transcriptome: Control vs. UV treatment
datasetPresenter.summary: Global gene expression in C. parvum oocysts (environmental stage) and oocysts treated with UV were determined by whole genome microarray.
datasetPresenter.description:
The effects of UV treatment on the Cryptosporidium parvum environmental stage (oocysts) were determined by whole genome microarray. C. parvum IOWA-1 oocysts were separated into two groups: untreated controls (4 samples) and UV-treated (4 samples; ID20 UV dose at 254 nm (2.8 mJ/cm2)). Oocyst samples were assayed via microarray following 0.5 hours recovery (2 untreated controls, 2 UV treated) or 5 hours recovery (2 untreated controls, 2 UV treated). The purified RNA was firstly reverse-transcribed into cDNA and then converted into cRNA probes labelled with Cy3 or Cy5 and hybridized to the CpArray15K (Agilent Technologies) microarray.
Note: There may be some minor differences between the results obtained here and those published by Zhang et al. This is due to the differences in data analysis methods. In the paper published by Zhang et al., only individual spots (values after LOWESS normalization) with p-values <0.05 across biological replicates were used to calculate fold changes.
datasetPresenter.protocol: two-condition experiment, control vs. UV treatment; two time points, 0.5h and 5h. Each time point, two biological replicates(1, 2) with two technique replicates(1-1,1-2; 2-1,2-2).

templateInjector.prop: UV-treated vs untreated control- 5 hr recovery=5 HR UV Treated;UV-treated vs untreated control- 0.5 hr recovery=0.5 HR UV Treated
UV-treated vs untreated control- 5 hr recovery=5 HR Control;UV-treated vs untreated control- 0.5 hr recovery=0.5 HRControl
C. parvum oocysts treated with UV compared to untreated. 0.5 and 5 Hour timepoints for each comparison
